title: You asked, we're answering: Your top questions about Covid-19 and vaccines
author: CNN's Holly Yan
description: CNN readers ask sharp questions about coronavirus every day. We're answering some of the most popular questions and busting myths with statistics and facts.
cleaned_text: CNN readers from around the world have asked more than 150,000 questions (and counting) about [coronavirus](https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-us-maps-and-cases/). We're reading as many as we can and answering some of the most popular questions here. Search by topic or by keywords (below) to find answers to your questions. If you have a question we haven't answered, [ask us here](https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/04/us/coronavirus-town-hall-questions/index.html). You can also [subscribe to our newsletter](https://www.cnn.com/specials/coronavirus-newsletter), Coronavirus: Fact or Fiction, and [listen to Dr. Sanjay Gupta's podcast](https://www.cnn.com/audio/podcasts/corona-virus) to learn more. In August, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention eliminated several recommendations for schools while continuing to emphasize other key Covid-19 precautions. Under the new guidelines, [the CDC no longer recommends](https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/11/health/cdc-covid-guidance-update/index.html): But the CDC said other precautions are still important. For example: White House Covid-19 Response Coordinator Dr. Ashish Jha said he anticipates "a very different school year" this year. "We should look forward to a school year where every child is in school in-person, full-time for the whole year," Jha said, stressing [the importance of vaccination for children and teachers](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html). "I think we have all the ability to do that." Updated boosters that will help the immune system fight Omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5 [will likely be available in early to mid-September](https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/16/health/biden-administration-covid-19-vaccines-tests-treatments/index.html), White House Covid-19 Response Coordinator Dr. Ashish Jha said August 16. "These are substantial upgrades in our vaccines in terms of their ability to prevent infection to prevent transmission," Jha said. As of August 13, the [highly contagious BA.4 and BA.5 strains made up the vast majority](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions) of new Covid-19 cases, according to estimates from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Both Pfizer and Moderna have been working on bivalent boosters — vaccines that include both the original formula [and a new one that targets the Omicron BA.4 and BA.5 subvariants](https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/04/health/updated-boosters-fall/index.html). If the shots meet US Food and Drug Administration standards, they will probably be available as early as September, [the FDA said.](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/29/health/updated-covid-boosters-fall/index.html) The [United Kingdom has already approved Moderna's bivalent booster](https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/15/europe/uk-moderna-vaccine-omicron-variant-approval-intl-gbr) for adults "after it was found to meet the UK regulator's standards of safety, quality and effectiveness," the UK government said in a statement August 15. Anyone age 5 and up who got a 2nd dose of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine at least 5 months ago [can now get a booster shot (or 3rd dose) of vaccine](https://www.cnn.com/2022/05/17/health/fda-covid-booster-kids-5-11/index.html). The US Food and Drug Administration issued a statement saying [2nd doses of the vaccine eventually wane](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-expands-eligibility-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine-booster-dose). The FDA said 3rd doses boosted antibody levels. Even though Covid-19 tends to be less severe among children, "the omicron wave has seen more kids getting sick with the disease and being hospitalized, and children may also experience longer term effects, even following initially mild disease," FDA Commissioner Dr. Robert M. Califf said in a [written statement](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-expands-eligibility-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine-booster-dose). "Vaccination continues to be the most effective way to prevent COVID-19 and its severe consequences, and it is safe," Califf said. "If your child is eligible for the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine and has not yet received their primary series, getting them vaccinated can help protect them from the potentially severe consequences that can occur, such as hospitalization and death." The [recommended gap between 2nd doses and booster doses](https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/03/health/covid-19-vaccine-booster-eligibility/index.html) of the Pfizer vaccine has been shortened - from 6 months to 5 months, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced in January. Those who got the 2-dose Moderna vaccine [should get a booster shot 6 months after the second dose](https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/29/health/cdc-booster-guidance-omicron/index.html), the CDC said. And those who got the single-dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine [should get a booster shot after 2 months](https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/29/health/cdc-booster-guidance-omicron/index.html). For booster shots, you don't have to get the same brand of vaccine that you got for your initial vaccination. The FDA has said [it's OK to mix and match brands for the booster dose](https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/20/health/moderna-johnson-vaccine-booster-fda-eua/index.html). Some [immunocompromised people ages 12 and older](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/immuno.html) and [all adults ages 50 and up](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/29/health/covid-second-booster/index.html) can [now get a 4th dose](https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-questions-answers/#is-it-time-to-get-another-booster-shot-who-can-get-a-4th-dose-of-vaccine-now) of the Pfizer/BioNTech or Moderna vaccines. Kids as young as 6 months old [can now start getting pediatric doses](https://www.cnn.com/2022/06/21/health/covid-vaccines-under-5-begin/index.html) of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine or Moderna vaccine. Parents can keep track of vaccine availability at [vaccines.gov](https://www.vaccines.gov/). The dosages of the vaccines for younger children are a fraction of the dosages for older children and adults. For kids as young as 6 months old, the US Food and Drug Administration has authorized 3 doses of the Pfizer vaccine or 2 doses of the Moderna vaccine. With the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said kids ages 6 months through 4 years [should get 3 doses at the following intervals](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Pfizer-BioNTech.html): With the Moderna vaccine, the CDC said children ages 6 months through 5 years should get their doses at the following intervals: With the [BA.5 variant](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/14/health/omicron-ba-5-variant-immunity-severity/index.html) sweeping the country — [particularly among young adults](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/13/health/under-50-second-boosters/index.html) — health officials have been [considering 2nd booster shots for healthy adults under 50](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/13/health/under-50-second-boosters/index.html). But not even the head of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases knows when additional doses might be authorized for all younger adults. " [Hopefully we'll get an answer reasonably soon](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/16/health/fauci-covid-second-boosters-adults-under-50/index.html)," Dr. Anthony Fauci told CNN on July 16. Right now, [anyone age 50 and up can get a 2nd booster shot](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/29/health/covid-second-booster/index.html). For those who got the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines, that typically means a 4th overall dose. [Some people under age 50 can also get a 2nd booster](https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-questions-answers/#is-it-time-to-get-a-2nd-booster-shot-who-can-get-a-4th-dose-of-vaccine-now) shot — for example, those who are moderately or severely immunocompromised. These people are at [greater risk of severe illness and death if they get Covid-19](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/immuno.html), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says. [According to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/immuno.html), you can be moderately or severely immunocompromised if you: BA.5 is an offshoot of the Omicron variant that's [now the dominant strain](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions) in the US, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Like previously dominant strains, BA.5 has mutations that have allowed it to spread easily and quickly overtake other variants. Specifically, BA.5 has [three mutations in its spike protein that make it better at infecting cells](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/14/health/omicron-ba-5-variant-immunity-severity/index.html) [and](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/14/health/omicron-ba-5-variant-immunity-severity/index.html) [better at slipping past immune defenses](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/14/health/omicron-ba-5-variant-immunity-severity/index.html). "But we do know it to be more transmissible and more immune-evading," Walensky said. "People with prior infection, even with BA.1 and BA.2, are likely still at risk for BA.4 or BA.5," CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky said. The reason at-home antigen tests expire is because Covid-19 test components "may degrade, or break down, over time," the [US Food and Drug Administration says](https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/coronavirus-covid-19-and-medical-devices/home-covid-19-diagnostic-tests-frequently-asked-questions). "Because of this, [expired test kits could give inaccurate test results](https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/coronavirus-covid-19-and-medical-devices/home-covid-19-diagnostic-tests-frequently-asked-questions)." But the [expiration dates for some at-home Covid-19 tests have been extended](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/21755878-abbott-announces-expiration-extensions-for-binaxnow-tests). That's because when at-home antigen tests first hit the market, manufacturers only had several months of data as to how long the tests would work effectively. "When the tests were first given the green light, when they were approved by the Food and Drug Administration, one of the things that the FDA asked the test developers to do is say, 'OK, if I have the test at home and I have them on the shelf or on my bookshelf, for how long will they still be accurate?'" [said Dr. William Schaffner](https://www.cnn.com/2022/04/25/health/expired-home-covid-19-tests-wellness/index.html), a professor of infectious diseases at Vanderbilt University Medical Center. "Of course, in the beginning when the tests were first developed, the manufacturers waited let's say 3 months or 6 months, and then they went to the Food and Drug Administration and said, 'Here is the data,'" Schaffner said. "Once the test manufacturer has more stability testing results, such as 12 or 18 months, the test manufacturer can contact the FDA to request that the FDA authorize a longer expiration date. When a longer expiration date is authorized, the test manufacturer may send a notice to customers to provide the new authorized expiration date, so the customers know how long they can use the tests they already have." Those wondering whether the expiration dates of their at-home tests have been extended can contact the manufacturer or visit its website. Much has changed since the beginning of the pandemic, including [the emergence of more contagious variants](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/14/health/omicron-ba-5-variant-immunity-severity/index.html), [waning immunity](https://www.cnn.com/2022/05/10/health/covid-19-fourth-vaccine-dose-wellness/index.html) from previous infection and initial vaccine doses, and [the need for booster shots](https://www.cnn.com/2022/05/10/health/covid-19-fourth-vaccine-dose-wellness/index.html) (or [2nd booster shots](https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-questions-answers/#is-it-time-to-get-a-2nd-booster-shot-who-can-get-a-4th-dose-of-vaccine-now)). What hasn't changed? [The need to isolate immediately](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/quarantine-isolation.html#iso) if you test positive for Covid-19 — regardless of whether you have symptoms, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. "Everyone who has presumed or confirmed COVID-19 should stay home and isolate from other people for at least 5 full days (day 0 is the first day of symptoms or the date of the day of the positive viral test for asymptomatic persons). They should wear a mask when around others at home and in public for an additional 5 days," [the CDC's website says](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/quarantine-isolation.html#iso). Exactly how long you isolate depends on whether you have symptoms and how long they last. According to the CDC: As for therapies, "it's important you [call your medical provider and ask if you are eligible for therapeutics](https://www.cnn.com/2022/05/18/health/coronavirus-omicron-masking-vaccines-wellness/index.html)," said emergency physician Dr. Leana Wen, professor of health policy and management at the George Washington University Milken Institute School of Public Health. For those who don't have a regular medical provider, "the federal government has a [therapeutics locator](https://covid-19-test-to-treat-locator-dhhs.hub.arcgis.com/), including a "test-to-treat" option where people can go to get tested, see an urgent care provider, and get the therapies all at the same location," Wen said. "Your local and state health departments will likely have additional information and resources, too." For [some people, yes](https://www.cnn.com/2022/04/27/health/paxlovid-covid-rebound/index.html). Paxlovid is a combination of two antiviral medications: nirmatrelvir and ritonavir. It's [now widely available at community pharmacies](https://www.fda.gov/drugs/news-events-human-drugs/fda-updates-paxlovid-health-care-providers), the US Food and Drug Administration says. "There is strong scientific evidence that it reduces the risk of hospitalization and death in patients with mild-to-moderate COVID-19 at high risk for progression to severe disease," [said Dr. John Farley](https://www.fda.gov/drugs/news-events-human-drugs/fda-updates-paxlovid-health-care-providers), director of the Office of Infectious Diseases in the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research's Office of New Drugs. But [even doctors are puzzled](https://www.cnn.com/2022/04/27/health/paxlovid-covid-rebound/index.html) as to why symptoms can return for some people [within two weeks](https://assets.researchsquare.com/files/rs-1588371/v1/48342d2c-b3ea-4228-b600-168fca1fded7.pdf?c=1650977883) of finishing their Paxlovid. Infectious disease expert Dr. Kent Sepkowitz is one of them. He, too is a ["rebounder" whose Covid-19 symptoms improved dramatically after taking Paxlovid, then returned](https://www.cnn.com/2022/05/10/opinions/paxlovid-rebound-covid-treatment-sepkowitz/index.html) several days later. Farley said the FDA "is aware of the reports of some patients developing recurrent COVID-19 symptoms after completing a treatment course of Paxlovid. In some of these cases, [patients tested negative on a direct SARS-CoV-2 viral test and then tested positive again](https://www.fda.gov/drugs/news-events-human-drugs/fda-updates-paxlovid-health-care-providers)." It's [not clear exactly how often](https://www.cnn.com/2022/04/27/health/paxlovid-covid-rebound/index.html) rebound cases happen after taking Paxlovid. As of this spring, a clinical trial of the medication was still ongoing. In [a statement to CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2022/04/27/health/paxlovid-covid-rebound/index.html), Pfizer - the maker of Paxlovid - said that in the clinical trial, a small number of patients in both the group taking placebo pills and the group taking Paxlovid experienced higher viral loads 10 to 14 days after starting treatment compared with their viral loads at day 5. Because investigators noted this in both groups, Pfizer said it doesn't believe the phenomenon is tied to the medication. Investigators saw no link between patients' viral loads and subsequent severe disease. "We remain confident in its clinical effectiveness at preventing severe outcomes from Covid-19 in high-risk patients," Pfizer said. The [Novavax vaccine is the 4th and latest Covid-19 vaccine authorized](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/19/health/novavax-vaccine-acip-vote/index.html) for use in the US. It's available in a 2-dose series for adults ages 18 and up. The Novavax vaccine uses totally different technology than the other 3 vaccines available in the US — those from Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson. When the genetic sequence for novel coronavirus was published, Novavax scientists identified the gene for the spike protein and created a modified version of that gene. Novavax researchers [cloned the genes into a baculovirus](https://www.novavax.com/our-unique-technology) that infects insects. They [then infected moth cells with that virus, prompting them to produce the coronavirus spike protein](https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/01/health/novavax-covid-19-vaccine-how-it-works-wellness-explainer/index.html). These virus-like nanoparticles were harvested to make Novavax's vaccine. But the Novavax vaccine is not infectious. " [We never touch the coronavirus itself](https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/01/health/novavax-covid-19-vaccine-how-it-works-wellness-explainer/index.html)," said Dr. Gregory Glenn, president of research and development for Novavax. After the vaccine is given to people, "they make an immune response that's very much focused just on the spike" protein, Glenn said. Late-stage trials found that the efficacy of the Novavax vaccine against mild, moderate and severe disease was 90.4%, according to the company. There is not sufficient evidence to determine the impact of the vaccine on transmission of the virus. In early July, Novavax said its vaccine showed "broad" immune response to currently circulating variants, including Omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5. The Novavax vaccine has some advantages and disadvantages over the others. "The hallmark of our vaccine is it gives a very strong immune response with very few side effects, and the dose is very small and [the vaccine can be stored with normal refrigerated temperatures](https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/01/health/novavax-covid-19-vaccine-how-it-works-wellness-explainer/index.html)," Glenn said. That can make the Novavax vaccine easier to transport and store than the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, which are more fragile and must be kept frozen. And people who have been hesitant to get a Covid-19 vaccine might be more comfortable getting Novavax shots because [the protein-based approach is a more traditional approach in vaccine development](https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/19/health/novavax-vaccine-acip-vote/index.html) compared to the mRNA vaccines from Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna. But the Novavax vaccine [is not yet authorized for use as a booster dose](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/booster-shot.html#when-you-can-get-booster), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. People who are boosted have more protection against Covid-19 illness and even infection compared to people who are [past due for a booster shot](https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-questions-answers/#who-can-get-a-booster-shot-now-are-kids-eligible-for-boosters-when-should-we-get-boosted) — and [significantly more protection than those who haven't been vaccinated at all](https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/21/health/cdc-omicron-booster-studies/index.html), studies suggest. In December 2021, when [the Omicron variant became dominant in the US](https://www.cnn.com/2021/12/20/health/us-coronavirus-monday/index.html), data from 25 state and local health departments revealed [a weekly average of 148.6 Covid-19 cases per 100,000 people who had been fully vaccinated and boosted](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7104e2.htm?s_cid=mm7104e2_w#T2_down), according to a study published by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Among those who had been fully vaccinated but not yet boosted, the average weekly rate jumped to [254.8 cases per 100,000](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7104e2.htm?s_cid=mm7104e2_w#T2_down). And for those who had not been vaccinated at all, [the rate of infection was significantly higher — 725.6 cases per 100,000](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7104e2.htm?s_cid=mm7104e2_w#T2_down). Another study showed booster shots helped prevent people from becoming sick with Omicron. An analysis of about 13,000 US Omicron cases found that the odds of developing a symptomatic infection were [66% lower for people who had received 3 doses of an mRNA vaccine compared to those who had received only 2 shots](https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/21/health/cdc-omicron-booster-studies/index.html), according to a study published [in the medical journal JAMA](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2788485?guestAccessKey=9c11371f-96e1-4181-a7eb-c87a13eb9df9&utm_source=For_The_Media&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=ftm_links&utm_content=tfl&utm_term=012122). The gap was even greater [between people who had been boosted and those who hadn't gotten a single dose](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2788485?guestAccessKey=9c11371f-96e1-4181-a7eb-c87a13eb9df9&utm_source=For_The_Media&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=ftm_links&utm_content=tfl&utm_term=012122) of vaccine. A CNN analysis of data from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed the [Johnson & Johnson vaccine had the lowest breakthrough infection rate](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/20/health/johnson-and-johnson-covid-19-vaccine/index.html) during a 5-week span starting in late December. In January, during the Omicron surge, breakthrough infections were highest among those who received the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine, followed by people who got the Moderna vaccine. Those vaccinated with the Johnson & Johnson shot had the lowest incidence of breakthrough infections. But any vaccine is better than no vaccine at all. During the Delta and Omicron surges, [unvaccinated people were more than twice as likely to get infected](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/20/health/johnson-and-johnson-covid-19-vaccine/index.html) compared to those who got Pfizer or Moderna shots. And the [odds of getting Covid-19 were more than 3 times higher for unvaccinated people](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/20/health/johnson-and-johnson-covid-19-vaccine/index.html) compared to those who got the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. A study published March 17 in the medical journal [JAMA Network Open](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2790204) found the Johnson & Johnson vaccine was 76% effective in preventing Covid-19 infections and 81% effective in preventing Covid-related hospitalizations before and during the Delta surge. The study also showed [the J&J vaccine provided lasting immunity at least 6 months](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/20/health/johnson-and-johnson-covid-19-vaccine/index.html) after vaccination. So while studies have shown the Pfizer and Moderna mRNA vaccines prompt a powerful immune response, it can wane over time. Johnson & Johnson's vaccine might not spark as strong of an immune response shortly after vaccination, but [it's known to have greater durability](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/20/health/johnson-and-johnson-covid-19-vaccine/index.html). "Over time, the efficacy of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines goes down, the efficacy of the J&J vaccines remains stable," [said Dr. Dan Barouch](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/20/health/johnson-and-johnson-covid-19-vaccine/index.html), director of the Center for Virology and Vaccine Research at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. But far [more Americans have received the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines than the Johnson & Johnson](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations_vacc-total-admin-rate-total) vaccine. In December, the [CDC recommended the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines over the Johnson & Johnson](https://www.cnn.com/2021/12/16/health/johnson-vaccine-acip-recommendation-mrna-preferred/index.html) shot due to data suggesting [a rare blood clotting syndrome called TTS](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#considerations-Janssen) is more common among some people who got a J&J vaccine - particularly women ages 30 to 49. The US Food and Drug Administration has [authorized second booster shots of the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for adults age 50 and older](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/29/health/covid-second-booster/index.html). Even healthy adults ages 50 and up can get the additional dose as early as 4 months after their 1st booster dose of any Covid-19 vaccine. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has given permissive recommendation for those additional boosters, [meaning Americans in that age group can get the extra shot if they want one](https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/29/health/covid-second-booster/index.html). But it's not an official recommendation. As for the rest of the general public, it's [possible a 4th dose might be recommended for healthy Americans](https://www.cnn.com/2022/02/19/health/fourth-covid-19-vaccine-dose-us/index.html) heading into the fall, said Dr. Peter Marks, director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research. But he said there's still much uncertainty as to how the pandemic may further evolve. A fall timeline could be convenient for people who want to get their flu shots at the same time. And respiratory viruses such as coronavirus and influenza tend to peak in the colder months. Since October, the FDA has allowed Americans ages 12 and up who are severely immune-deficient to get 4 doses of the Pfizer/BioNTech or Moderna vaccines. [According to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/immuno.html), people are considered moderately or severely immunocompromised if they have: A 2nd booster shot (or the 4th overall dose) of the Moderna or Pfizer/BioNTech mRNA vaccines appeared to be safe and gave [a "substantial" boost to immunity](https://www.cnn.com/2022/05/10/health/covid-19-fourth-vaccine-dose-wellness/index.html) when given about 7 months after the 1st booster (or the 3rd overall dose), according to a new study published May 9. "Fourth-dose Covid-19 mRNA booster vaccines are well tolerated and boost cellular and humoral immunity," UK scientists wrote in the study published in [The Lancet](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/21959777-uk-scientists-share-findings-from-a-study-involving-4th-doses-or-2nd-boosters-of-mrna-vaccines). "Peak responses after the fourth dose were similar to, and possibly better than, peak responses after the third dose." The researchers gave study participants a half dose of the Moderna vaccine or a full dose of the Pfizer vaccine in a random selection in January, about 7 months after they received their first booster. The 2nd booster didn't seem to have any major side effects. The biggest complaints were arm pain and fatigue. The additional booster also generated an immune response at day 14 that was higher than that at day 28 after the 3rd dose of the Pfizer or Moderna Covid-19 vaccine. Moderna's fourth dose seemed to do slightly better than Pfizer's, but it's unclear why. Scientists said 4th doses of either vaccine generated what scientists called a "significant fold change" in protective antibodies and also boosted T-cells. Antibodies are a first line of immune protection that can stop a virus from infecting cells. T-cells come in later and destroy infected cells. T-cells can't protect against mild infections, but they can keep infections from progressing to severe disease. The researchers also found that some people who had higher levels of antibodies before their 4th doses of vaccine had only "limited" boosting. Those with a history of Covid-19 had a similar limited response. The authors say this suggests there may be a ceiling or maximum response that can come with a 4th vaccine dose. Many Americans were confused when Dr. Anthony Fauci told PBS that the US was "out of the pandemic phase" — but told CNN the next day that the pandemic was not over.
